review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment: Don't like much this notation. As there is poly_n it should 'X_n^i or 'X^i_n but I guess this is not possible

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment: Should lagragian polynomials be defined first in poly. Then lifted as a base in polyn

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
- `'X_n^i` would conflict with the multivariate polynomials of Pierre-Yves
- `'X^i_n` might be conflict with `'X^i` from poly...

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: maybe.... not sure about this... do Lagrange polynomial have another use than as interpolation or basis of R_n[X]?

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment: I don't know, I would not search interpolation under polyn

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: @thery yes I think so, provided `(i : 'I_n)`, you are right, I think this is the way to go... and same for `lagrange`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: ok! Do you have an opinion on whether `x` should be of type `seq F`, `nat -> F`, `n.-tupleF` or `F ^ n`?

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment:
a priori n.-tuple F :
  lagrange takes a tuple and returns a tuple.

We could also have
F^n 
then lagrange should return a  {poly_n ...}^ n

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: lagrange should return a basis of a vector space, so it must be a tuple

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: But if it returns a tuple, then it should be of type `n.-tuple {poly_n F}` because otherwise there is no way to get it canonically.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
so we duplicate `lagrange`? One in poly `lagrange: n.tuple F -> n.-tuple {poly F}` and one in npoly of type `lagrange_basis : n.tuple F -> n.-tuple {poly_n F}` with a theorem: ``lagrange_basis`_i = lagrange`_i :> {poly F}``, and no possible canonical structure (because the previous equality will not be jugmental).
Or could it be jugmental?

commits.author: CohenCyril
commits.message:
The vector space of bounded degree polynomials

Includes a decidable predicate for irreducibly of polynomials of
bounded size over a finite field, and the 'X^i and lagrange basis.
